title: Inside the Game: No. 6 Notre Dame at No. 12 Clemson
text: Email @Aaron_Brenner Oct 2 2015 10:13 am Oct 2 10:15 am A worker helps construct the set of ESPN's College GameDay on Bowman Field in Clemson during a light rain shower. × CLEMSON – The weekend of events in Clemson led by No. 6 Notre Dame’s trip to play the 12th-ranked Tigers has not changed course in the face of uncertain weather patterns, as of Friday morning. “Clemson athletics officials met this morning and confirmed our ability to operate the game tomorrow, and as of 9:30 a.m. still feel confident in the resources needed,” Clemson’s official statement read. “We spoke with Highway Patrol and Campus Police this morning and confirmed their manpower will be available. Facilities has confirmed power, plumbing and operations are still good to go. Playing surface is still good.” College GameDay remains scheduled for Bowman Field from 9-12 a.m. Saturday, which is open to fans. On Friday, the men’s and women’s soccer games helping dedicate Riggs Field and a baseball intrasquad scrimmage are still on as scheduled. Hurricane Joaquin has been predicted to begin traveling east from the Bahamas, but heavy rainfall remains in the forecast for the weekend. The university is urging fans preparing to visit Clemson to travel together and avoid grass lots. “Grass lots may be limited and we’re working on alternatives,” the statement read. “We encourage people to carpool or consolidate into cars with paved parking by meeting off campus to limit cars in grass lots. We’ll update parking lot information this afternoon.” According to the university, ESPN and ABC “is running 100 percent on generator power” and power usage is being decreased in Riggs Field and Memorial Stadium. Reported power outages on campus do not include Memorial Stadium. Keywords
